memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2275

TITLE OF BILL:

An act to amend the penal law, in relation to excluding child sexual
abuse from the definition of the crime of incest

PURPOSE:

This bill defines the crime of incest to exclude child sexual abuse.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Section 1 of this bill amends the first undesignated paragraph of
section 255.25 of the penal law. Current law provides that a person is
guilty of incest when "a person" engages in sexual intercourse with
someone whom is closely related to them. This section deletes "a person"
and replaces it with "an adult."

Section 2 enacts this bill on the first of November next succeeding the
date on which it shall become law.

JUSTIFICATION:

Currently, sex with a child under eleven is a Class B felony, punishable
by up to twenty-five years in prison. However, if the sexually abused
child is closely related to the perpetrator, the prosecutor has an
option of charging that adult with a lesser charge of incest. Incest is
a Class E felony which carries a maximum of four years in prison and a
minimum of probation. In other words this loophole may allow adults to
engage in sexual relations with children without fear of incarceration.
It is defined as an "offense affecting the marital relationship" and not
as a sex offense.

By changing the word "person" to "adult," this bill would close the
"incest loophole" because the the word "person" implies any individual,
including children. "Adult" excludes sexual relations with children from
the definition of incest altogether. Thus a perpetrator could only be
prosecuted using New York's child sex offense laws. This bill ensures
that all children who are victims of rape by their own parent or close
relative would have equal access to protection under New York State law.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

This act shall take effect on the first of November next succeeding the
date on which it shall become law.
